Posts.Title: Husband diagnose with prostate cancer...

Posts.Content: He's dad was diagnose from prostate cancer at 68, so he goes to yearly checkup. In november the Dr felt something he did not like so he schedule a biopsy without even waiting for the PSA results. The Biopsy was done on Dic. 18, and we got the results 2 days after. He made the decision of surgery without any learning. For his Dr. and himself with he's age surgery was the best option as the cancer should be small and hopefully not metastasized and surgery is the only way to take the cancer out. The Biopsy was 1core out of 12 3+4 30% We do not have the John Hopkins reading yet, I'm hopping for the end of this week. i've tried to slow him down on the surgery rush, but if it was up to him he would have had it done yesterday! He's only waiting till feb cause the dr. Said he need at least 6 weeks post biopsy for the inflammation to go down. Thanks again Ek
Posts.Title: Husband diagnose with prostate cancer...

Posts.Content: Hi, I'm new around here. My was just diagnose with prostate cancer. He's 48, hi's PSA was 2.5, 1 out of 12 biopsy samples came out positive, Gleason 3+4. He decided right away on DaVinci surgery with Dr. Patel. I on the other hand would be taking things a little bit slower. I just asked the Dr. for the biopsy slides to be send to John Hopkins for a second opinion on the pathology reading, but on the meantime we visit Dr. Patel and scheduled his surgery for beginning of february... Many questions, We are going to be 1 week in a hotel for the surgery (we live in miami, dr is in orlando). Any suggestions on making our stay more comfortable. We have 3 kids, 16-14 and 11, we already spoke with them about the cancer and the surgery, but, should we bring them to orlando with us?, have someone bring them to visit for the day? Just let them spend the week here with family/friends and see them a week latter (we are planing on returning after the catheter has been removed) How much should i bug hubby with my opinions/help or let him be? Thanks for all your help EK

Posts.Title: Husband diagnose with prostate cancer...

Posts.Content: Ok. Thought i owed everyone an update, specially after all the help and support you have all given us. It's been 4 days since my husband surgery, and as unreal as it might sound it has really been easier then what we expected. Thursday (surgery day) was a little scary cause it took him a lot to regulate his breathing after anesthesia, so he went to the room late and did not get to walk until around 8pm. By friday 10am they were kicking us out from the room!!! We have walked a little every day, we were even able to go for a stroll around town for a couple of hours this afternoon!!! Tomorrow afternoon they are removing the catheter and giving us the pathology... The catheter is uncomfortable but he has gotten used to it and the changing of the bags is now a snap... It's funny... We were soooo afraid of the catheter and we are no afraid of not having it and not having control of his bladder... Best recommendations I can give: * Go in with a positive attitude, there is no GOOD way around it, so stay positive and go positive into your surgery. * If possible have a "support network" the company, even if they can not help, they can distract you. * Basitracin-neosporim-ycream, any of them... Have lots available. * Don't be afraid of the catheter or the bags changes *If having surgery out of town, instead of staying at a hotel, try renting an apartment. We were able to find a time share kind of hotel with a separate living room and a full kitchen, so we have been able to rest and eat home cook meals that are easy on the stomach. *I know it may sound cliche but chicken soup, more even, a good matzeball soup, makes a very good, easy on the tommy, and easy on the soul, meal! *ask for extras of everything at the hospital, we have 2 big bags, 2 leg bags and 2 pairs of compression socks!!! Thanks again for all your support Esther
